comment: I was not looking forward to this class based on the reviews below, but I had an amazing experience. My class was in person and only had 8 people in it which made it an engaging environment. She uses lots of case studies and has great real world applications. She was constantly asking for feedback and adjusted accordingly. 10/10 would take again.
The work was set at the right level of graduate work- I enjoyed the case studies especially.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Group projects

comment: She's a nice professor with many Connect Assignments + Tests, Lots of Discussion Posts, & a Group Project. We also had weekly discussion posts with a group we were assigned. I slacked & could've made an A had I stepped up at the end of the semester, but I did finish her class with 88.78%!

I took International HRM with Dr. Adams. She is very nice but she provides vague instructions for assignments & is a very tough grader. She does not know how to use technology very well. She will randomly change assignments & due dates. She takes forever to grade assignments. You have to teach yourself everything. I am very lucky I got a B!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Professor Adams is genuinely a nice lady but probably the worst professor I've ever had. She randomly added assignments without warning, gave more homework than I've ever had despite knowing everyone works full time outside of school, and wrote the most terribly worded and hardest graded tests I've ever taken. Absolutely avoid if possible.

Easily the worst professor I took at KSU, including undergrad. She had no idea what she was doing and clearly did not care to learn. Assignments would open and close at random and you might have half of one business day to complete it. The content was incredibly easy yet her grading was as disorderly as her class was. Avoid at all costs.
I have never seen a professor as unorganized as she is. She changed the coursework multiple times with very little notice.

Awful! Only two weeks into the class and there is no organization at all.  There are no clear instructions. For an MBA level course, she gives an undergrad workload - just busy work.  She is the only option for this course right now and it is very unfortunate for all that have to endure this class this semester.

Biggest obstacle for her was the technology. It was her 1st semester at KSU and not sure she had used D2L before. Criticisms on her organization and sticking to the syllabus are valid, but outside of the final (20% of grade) the class was not difficult. Case studies, group presentations and McGraw Hill lets you check your answer tests and quizzes.

I do not understand how this woman was hired as a professor. She refused to follow the syllabus, constantly added new assignments with little to no guidance and then graded them harshly, and never actually taught us anything sufficient. The class is mostly common sense, and there was no real world application. Avoid her at all costs. Waste of time.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Before three weeks were up more than half the class had dropped and I should have done the same. This professor ruined an otherwise great MBA program for me because of how bad she is at teaching. She made up assignments for us to do that weren't in the syllabus and when called out for it she made it our fault. Do yourself a favor and dont take

In all my years as a student, Professor Adams has been the most unprofessional and unwilling-to-teach professor I have ever had. She often posts incorrect information to each class and is entirely self-taught through McGraw Hill. There is no effort to teach, and she punishes the class when she does something wrong in their disorganization.

I hate to say this but this class and its facilitation were the biggest waste of time I've ever had. I ended up having to teach myself everything because it was impossible to follow the lectures. She has so many degrees and certifications but couldn't figure out how to end class on time every, single, lecture. Disappointing to say the least

This class is common sense, so I don't know why it was so disorganized. Professor Adams made up assignments and gave us only 4 days turn around time. Super inconsistent with the syllabus. When you work full time and try to go to school the least you can expect is consistency, and this was not it. Seriously, do not take her

Absolutely terrible. Worst class taken in MBA. Disorganized, changed dates, was flexible and nice to talk to but never seemed on point in class. This class was structured like undergrad, lots of busy work, little application, read and quiz every week. Must have text. McGraw Hill will teach you, not Dr. Adams. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Lots of homework

comment: Very unconfident teaching a class. Lectures are all over the place and very hard to follow. She basically gave up trying to have class discussions and forced the class to present all the discussions while she sat back and contributed nothing. Very unpleasant experience for a Master's level course. I would avoid

Arguably one of the most unprofessional professors I have had in 6+ years of higher education. Terrible time management, vague instructions, assignments created frequently out of thin air, and inconsistent with the syllabus. Gaslit the class when she asked for feedback. Completely unacceptable for a graduate level class. Take anyone else.

DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR!!!! If you are in the Graduate program and there is another option for a professor take anyone else but her. The professor is disorganized, unprofessional, no clear guidelines/expectations from her. Expect her to constantly change due dates and add assignments that weren't part of the syllabus. Avoid if possible.

The professor does not teach anything in the course; it is entirely taught by McGraw Hill Connect learning, even the proctored exams. Discussions weekly, with a Group Project discussion at the end. 

They will assign you to random project groups; due dates are different.
Some people have five days to submit, and others have three weeks. Beware.

The workload is too heavy, especially for a graduate level course. The class had around 40 students, but now only 20 remain. The main reasons being the workload and the fact that she can never make up her mind about assignments and deadlines making it extremely difficult to plan. She also does not take well to criticism and is easily offended.
